commentBody:
1. Nice puzzle!
2. The fact that people young enough to have done anything on Discord in elementary school are now also old enough to construct NYT crossword puzzles is...something alright. Excuse me while I turn to dust.
Fun, fast, and yummy!  A perfect treat to end my Monday on!  Congrats!
I think this really should have been published on a Monday.
Great puzzle from someone who is younger than most of my dental crowns.
Very Monday-ish.

Congrats on the debut! And thanks for the pointer to the Crossword Discord. The link to it needs to be fixed, however. It has a trailing paren that breaks it. The correct link is: https://discord.gg/uahCdxA3GZ

Clever theme, though I think at least one clue should have referred at least tangentially to the movie "E.T.", as Reese's Pieces figure into an early scene where Elliott tries to lure the alien back to his home.

I didn't know until checking Wikipedia that Steven Spielberg originally intended to use M&M's, but Mars (the giant candy maker) refused to grant permission.
Congrats on the puzzle! Loved the theme. Hope to see more from you in the future!

The solve took me 4 minutes less than this Monday, even though I've never heard of REESES PIECES and despite the fact in this part of the world footballs are rarely thrown, and when they are (on throw-ins and by the goalkeeper) they don't spiral - that generally only happens on kicks. Also, RENE DESCARTES was the only spanner I knew instantly. I needed loads of crosses for the song, and I didn't know the campaigning expression. Still, I enjoyed most of the fill.

RAVEL was new to me, much like "licit" in previous puzzles. Interesting.

The theme... Well, like I said, I'm unfamiliar with the product, and there was something unsatisfying about the fact there was no real connection between the "themed" entries and candy, as such. 

Oh, and, I just realized Polish Santa doesn't have helpers, ELFIN or otherwise, or at least he didn't in my childhood in the 1980s. He has his flying sled and reindeer (unnamed, for us), but that's it. He puts presents under the Christmas tree on Xmas Eve (when we have an evening feast), and nobody leaves milk and cookies for him. 

My parents agreed to tell me the truth as soon as I first asked if Santa was real. I was six or so. My father knew a guy in the 1960s who still believed in Santa in his teens, and was mocked mercilessly for it. My parents wanted to spare me similar humiliation, and they weren't big on the supernatural, anyway.

Kids these days! Next you'll see at grade school (r)(e)c(e)(s)s p(e)(s)ky six year olds constructing puzzles in the sandbox! Many an I.R.S. employee...I was thinking, hmmm, three letters: RTD ? ILL ? OUT ? NOT ? SAD ? CUT ? I love Descartes, the great doubter. In fact, his fuller statement was "Dubito, ergo cogito, ergo sum" -- I doubt, therefore I think, therefore I am. He also wrote, I have made a point of doubting all my previously held beliefs. To begin with doubt, yet be hopeful, optimistic even, can there be a better method of cogitation? You can see it in Frans Hals' portrait of him: the doubt, the questioning, the sharpness and insight, and there's tiredness there too, a sallow complexion reflecting his inner struggles. "https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg
Congratulations on a great Tuesday puzzle. I tend to solve NW to SE. The reveal at the end that the constructor was a TEEN, made my day. A big tip of the hat from a septuagenarian.

First time commenting‚Ä¶

How often do solvers use or look at the theme on a Monday/Tuesday puzzle to help solve the crossword? I am usually trying to finish it as quickly as I can and rarely look or think about the theme. 

Some themes are clever and jump at you during or after you finish the puzzle and bring a smile to your face.

Minutes after raving on Facebook about how fantastic students at the University I work for are, three in particular that I had the great pleasure to recently interview for a student job in my office, and the great sadness to have to choose only one, then I come out here and solve a very fine puzzle created by a high schooler!

It wasn't the first time I've raved about how terrific our students are, I'm certain it won't be the last.  

This proud GenXer genuinely wishes to never hear another negative thing about the younger generations. Especially because it's often so unimportant whatever the differences are, trendy things and what not. 

No one ever paid GenX any mind, which I'd say we're all pretty cool with, so I guess I don't have gripes with anyone. Ha!

Anyhow, learned a new fact about PELE! I'll have to impress my husband, a huge PELE fan, with that one. 

SPaRRELED and AgERTO! Heaven's to Betsy, the NYT has made a grievous error!  Har!! My only hang up was putting agE instead of ILE at 48 down, so that was the last little bit I needed to clean up. 

Fun puzzle with a very sweet theme!! 

Congrats on your debut Mr. Krishnamurthy and best of luck in college! Your generation is giving me great hope for the future in a time that feels otherwise grim and perilous. I'm grateful for the opportunity to be part of it in my own limited way.  

Hope you can find the time to make more puzzles as your college workload revs up. ‚ò∫Ô∏è  

Thank you!
Great puzzle, Tarun!  Congrats on acceptance into the Honors College at SDSU.  My granddaughter was just recruited there to play basketball. Go Aztecs!
A really fun puzzle! Also as a geriatric millennial I‚Äôm proud for knowing both the Beatles song (I walked down the aisle to this classic) and the modern lingo for shady.

Great puzzle, with a theme that helped the solve. Tarun sounds from his comments like a really nice, smart, teen. I'm looking forward to living long enough to solve puzzles from him featuring "Twenties", "Thirties", etc., as he ages.
The clue for 14A reminded me of this customizable little plastic record I got from Dad when I was around 10 or so! üòç Anyone else remember this? https://youtu.be/2Qu042-1WmM?si=gdAGKVw3AFuyfdlX

Nice relaxing puzzle after a frustrating afternoon and evening.

Who would have thought that a crash and fire on I-4 this morning would create havoc on roadways ten miles away for the rest of the day. I'll spare you the details, but traffic was still backed up at 10 this evening.

Anyway, the puzzle was pretty straightforward, and solved readily. Didn't really pay attention to the circles until I hit the revealer. Theme answers were filled in with just a few crosses each, and the clue for the revealer(s) made solving that a snap.

Now to scoot my chair over to my shelves where I have a small supply of the goodies that are starring in this puzzle.

Thanks, Tarun, nice puzzle and nice NYT debut!
Great work, Tarun!
Bravo, Tarun! A fun puzzle to solve and I enjoyed the theme and its conceit!
Am I the only person who has never heard the phrase PRESSES THE FLESH in their life?

A fine Tuesday puzzle, with thoughtful clues.  Descartes would have been proud of you, Tarun, and delighted to appear in your puzzle.

Thank you, and good for us that you got on early start on constructing puzzles.  I hope this means that you'll be with us for a good long time.

What a fun and lively puzzle, Tarun! Can‚Äôt wait to solve your next one.

Best of luck in your studies!
Bruce‚Äôs Philosopher‚Äôs Song popped into mind instantly (I drink therefore I am) one of Monty Python‚Äôs finest but would probably not pass the modern censors.
Such a fun puzzle. Thanks, Tarun!
really delightful Tarun! such a fun puzzle!
I've never seen it spelled "spiralled", with two "L"s.
Easy-peasy!  Could have been a Monday.  Well below my average time but fun nevertheless‚Ä¶

Fantastic work, Tarun! Even more impressive that you are a mere one year younger than my middle child. Congratulations on your debut and your acceptance into SDSU‚Äôs Honor College in Neuroscience - both notable achievements! I also have a degree in neuroscience from UCR - a fascinating field of study that I‚Äôm sure you will enjoy. I hope to see more of your construction in future grids as your studies allow. I loved this one to PIECES.

Yum! Reeses. 

Oh wait. Pieces. 

To me, Reeses Pieces are the raisins of candy. They're great when you're expecting them. Not so great when you thought you were getting M&Ms or chocolate chip cookies.  At least they're not Skittles!

You know what's better than all of them? Tr[es] Lech[es] Cak[es]! Thanks for including it in the constructor's notes, Tarun! Great job on a fun puzzle!

And thanks for the link to the Discord server. I removed Discord from my phone a while back because it was too addictive. I'm very tempted to reinstall it and check out the Crossword community there.

I don't imagine this puzzle will take many solvers 23:01, but it gets me to bed on time.

Linguist though I've been I didn't know anything about Urdu until I saw 51D when I suddenly learned it was Indo-European. So much like Hindi.

Nice job, Tarun! Wait. Now I want a Reese‚Äôs Mini Peanut Butter Cup. 

Great luck at SDSU!
This one whipped by in typical Tuesday time, but I took nearly 3 minutes on today‚Äôs mini. Yikes! Just could not get a foothold till I looked up 4D. And to think I just got some new 4D.
This was really satisfying, hope to see more from this constructer.

I was a little upset when I saw 42A, but this changed my mind: https://english.stackexchange.com/a/178161 47A threw me off a little bit. Personally I think a more fitting word would be a derivative of ‚Äúspin‚Äù, but English sometimes can be nonsensical to someone that took 24D.

Am I the only one to note that it is the consumption of a certain bird that is used to refer to a humiliation? The consumption of soil is used to refer to a fall or wipe out. Totally different thing. Where‚Äôs the editor?
Fantastic puzzle - please make more!
And just when I was getting tired of Oreos, this lovely puzzle comes and offers a breath of fresh air!
Nice easy puzzle after a particularly stress-laden day. Even got to finish it much earlier than I've been doing lately. Saw Reese's Pieces right away, which made it go much quicker.
PRESSESTHEFLESH is new to me but not anymore!
The kids are alright, says this geriatric millennial.

When I got to 21A, I reminded myself that this was the NYT and therefore I should use US spelling. Of course, as the example was a British theatre, I should have kept to what I would have entered naturally.
New Tuesday PB! Thanks Tarun - I loved the clueing for URDU, MEALS, and of course, TEEN :)
Congratulations, Tarun. What a lovely puzzle. Best wishes for your next adventure. Hope there's time for constructing puzzles.
Can someone explain ‚ÄúRide-or-dies, in brief‚Äù?

Very clever construction , although I found it a bit tricky for a Tuesday, but not for most.  As always my poor memory slows me down a bit, and today it was  26A. I actually did a paper on him at university, (1956) but I needed virtually all the letters to get it.  Looking forward to more from Tarun.
Well, congrats Ian. You stumped me. First mini I've done where I didn't get s single clue.  üòÜ

Excellent conception and execution! 

I only wish I had your talent...especially at your young age!

WOW

Sorry to be a northern downer, but in 14 more days, there goes the sun.

Speaking of which, this time of year, surely elf out?

As ET would say: a phone-hominal puzzle.
Lots of fun! Good luck with all your future undertakings!
Fresh and fun, Tarun! Good luck in college.
Great puzzle, Tarun.  Congratulations!

A theme whose answers cover a lot of realms ‚Äì music, philosophy, and politics, all tied together with candy.

Outside the theme, words I love ‚Äì BASH, TEMPEST, SPIRALLED (spelled either way), HONE, SPUR, RAVEL, and especially the terrific FIRM BELIEF (which, by the way, is a Times answer debut).

Then a moment of love for our quirky language when I looked at the answer ADMIT and saw that it can mean both to let in and to let out.

‚ÄúRide or die‚Äù is new to me, but its meaning was immediately clear, and the answer BFF came out with a double aha ‚Äì one for cracking the riddle, and the other for learning a new and beautiful/perfect phrase.

Suddenly this simple but charming theme wasn‚Äôt alone in the box.  No, it was nested among things that made me happy.

And thus, today‚Äôs jaunt was more than just a fill-in, but rather something richer ‚Äì the box as balm, the box as beauty.  What a lovely outing ‚Äì thank you, Tarun!
Did anyone else made the mistake of trying YELLOWSUBMARINE for 17A? It has the right number of letters, although I'll admit I don't know who is the writer or singer.

Tuesday Strands
If it's Tuesday, it must be Belgium?

Avoid spoilers until after View All Replies, please.

Strands #471
‚ÄúMake it work‚Äù
üîµüîµüü°üîµ
üîµüîµ

Northwest word tickles me.
Just had to grab myself a Reese's Piece! Yum/
Overall fun but spiraled out of control with the extra L in 47A. Yes I‚Äôm aware it‚Äôs technically acceptable but not commonly used and still a reach.

Lovely puzzle. 
My first question is; how else would you spell SPIRALLED Sam??
Yes! A language I know. We had two terms in secondary (high) school learning URDU. It was specific to our area as there was a high number of students from the large  Urdu speaking community in our city. I‚Äôve forgotten most of it, but do remember how to count to ten. Sadly it was halted due to a very vocal minority who resented such inter community encouragement.  Sine things don‚Äôt change.

Big props to you, Tarun. I've been doing the NYT puzzles for many years, and couldn't begin to construct one, so I especially admire someone as young as you who can do that. 
I enjoyed the fresh cluing. 

I hope you can take time from your studies to make more puzzles for us.
Another complaint about SPIRALLED and Sam's explanation.  Neither works.

I've fallen behind about a week or so on my crossword solving as my mother passed away on June 4th. She lived a good, long life and had a wonderful memorial. Her love of crosswords (and all word games) inspired me to enjoy them as well.

Doing the puzzle and being a part of the crossword community are a couple of the few things that give me joy lately, so I'm grateful for that. 

This was a fun puzzle to restart my (not so important) streak. I found it fresh and a little sassy.

Never have I ever heard the phrase PRESSES THE FLESH. Although I will admit to a little flesh-pressing from time to time, it was not in a way which would help me achieve elected office.

Although, in these times, not prohibit it, either.

Reeses Pieces--yuck!

I‚Äôll chip in with a Tuesday twofer of ballads since the subject is candy‚Ä¶I delivered all kinds of the sweet stuff (and fresh nuts) to kiosks in my heyday. One route was in Manhattan, another upstate and yet another on L. I.; eats were a perk. And I was not shy about capitalizing on them. https://youtu.be/5ebTjIsqen8?si=pEXj8Eq07uAWL4ju https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_cqnLclE2gU&list=RD_cqnLclE2gU&start_radio=1 I BID You Adieu, Bru
Thanks for a great puzzle, many congratulations on your graduation, and best wishes for your next chapter!

Cute theme, though almost too simple. 

Liked the left-right symmetry, and the clever connection of (The) TEMPEST to THEATRE via "Shakespeare's Globe, e.g."
Also liked having TEMPEST and TENPAST in the same grid.

SPIRALLED with doubled Ls feels wrong to me, especially since the emphasis in "spiral" is on the initial syllable. (As opposed to, for example, "corralled".) But apparently it's a perfectly acceptable alternate spelling. LISTICLE also feels wrong to me, and in this case I hope the word dies a quick and uneasy death. I'd even prefer TESTICLE---I wonder if I've just fed this post to the emus. We'll see.

Two mistakes slowed me down. I entered ALIVETO instead of ALERTTO for "Aware of, as dangers". And SOLES instead of SORES for "Sensitive skin spots". Fixed both via crosses.

Nice Tuesday puzzle!

Delightful! Who ever would have imagined that a teenager could make such a puzzle? I enjoyed solving it. 

Did the constructor originally come from India? I ask because of the British spellings of theater and spiraled. Neuroscience. I love it!

Despite the fact that the puzzle was made by a teenager, there is nothing childish or teenage about it. It's sophisticated.

This may lead to an unhealthy SPIRAL, but I need some explanation regarding the photo that accompanies today's "Wordplay" column.  Is it simply that the children depicted are "over-"doing the amount of "time" that they spend watching television?  I SUS-pect that something else must be going on.  

(And why pick such a banal clue as the title of the article?)

Yes, I know, I'm SPIRAL(L)ING.
As a Canadian solver, I did a little eye roll at first and dutifully typed in THEATER. Then I realized the builder had spelled it the right way (üòâ) ‚Ä¶ a small joy in a busy day. Thanks!

As someone who worked in professional theatre (and yes, in the US, most theatre professionals use the British/Canadian spelling), I was very happy that my first instinct to spell THEATRE correctly was spot on.

How cool to have a puzzle published in your teens! Good luck at SDSU, Tarun!
I admit....I don't like anything peanut or peanut butter flavored. Also milk chocolate, coconut, ketchup....
Yeah - I'm basically close to being voted out of my family!
But the puzzle was smooth and crunchy for a Tuesday.

My freshman year in college, my floor mates gave me a plaque that said "Bless This Mess." So, yes, I was embarrassed enough to clean up my act. 

Even so, my first guess at the clue was "small." I figured out MESSY pretty quickly, though, and probably blushed as I filled it in. 

REESES PIECES came quickly, and the rest followed in Tuesday fashion. A lovely puzzle; tasty, too. Probably my only candy for today, since I gained about 8 lbs on our cruise last week. Down 2 so far...
It‚Äôs interesting that this teen constructor knew about a female tennis player from the 1950s, but I never saw that particular entry before in any puzzle constructed by oldsters .
Perfect Tuesday puzzle with unique clues that were challenging yet figureoutable.  Hope to see more from this clever puzzle maker!
What a clever, fresh puzzle! Quite impressive!
What a great puzzle without all of the usual suspects. Looking forward to more from this young talent!

Nice puzzle! 

I agree there probably was a missed opportunity for an E.T. reference -- but that's probably a generational thing! 

Some really nice clueing, such as 5A&D. And nice echoes throughout the grid: the parallel horological TEN PAST and TIME OFF; current parlance SUS and PIC sitting across from each other on a row; BREAST and CREST (phonetic), PAL and FELLA (meaning)... 

After *eight weekends in a row* of unseasonably cold and rainy weather here in the Northeast, I'm of the FIRM BELIEF that HERE COMES THE SUN. (And the weather forecast backs me up!!)

Thanks for the sweet puzzle, Tarun!

I was just listening to Here Comes The Sun a few days ago, trying desperately to believe.

Fantastic puzzle, constructor!! gotTA RUN!
Very good puzzle! Perfect for a Tuesday. Thanks.

Nothing from Munster Mike yet, so here's something in the meantime:

Rene Descartes walks into a bar and orders a shot. After he slugs it down, the bartender says, "Would you like another?"

"I think not," Descartes replies.

And poof! He vanishes!

Be sure to tip your server...

Busy morning - late to the party. Anyway - nice Tuesday puzzle - struggled a bit early on but the first two theme answers came smoothly and then it all fell together. Interesting puzzle find today - a Sunday from April 26, 2009 by Trip Payne with the title "Roughly speaking." Puzzle had more than 30 rebus squares all of which were either ER or UM. Some sample answers: S(ER)IALN(UM)BERS CONS(UM)(ER)INT(ER)EST B(UM)P(ER)TOB(UM)P(ER) NEWSPAP(ER)COL(UM)N And a whole bunch of others. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/26/2009&g=3&d=D ...
I wish reeses pieces were real

Sigh.
Bright, breezy and quick... but then no happy music.
Having deaf friends who had to learn American Sign Language when they visited the USA led me down the garden path. (Does that idiom cross the Atlantic successfully?) I was genuinely gratified to see a minority problem acknowledged as I typed aSL into the grid. The giant company in the cross rang a bell, but RaI seemed as good a  spelling as REI.

I was briefly too clever by half, at first typing the American spelling of THEATRE into the grid, but was then gratified to correct it to the very appropriate British version.

To quote an old Heinlein novel from memory, "A spiral is not a compatible orbit". Presumably it's a point on the surface of the thrown football that spirals, rather than the football itself, but I'm prepared to be corrected (if astonished) by those who know about these things. 
Curiously, my Oxford American Dictionary lists SPIRALLED as an alternative to "spiraled", specifically under "American football", so there are clearly considerations here beyond my ken.

When I was a kid, my soccer team got tickets to a match between the NY Cosmos and the Washington Diplomats. (At RFK Stadium, flashing back to yesterday.) It was a huge deal, as we got to see Pel√© play. At the time, he was the only soccer player everybody knew. But even in the NASL days, America was where players came for one last paycheck before retiring.
Great puzzle Tarun! Keep  at it and you will undoubtedly end up on a Crossword Listicle in the future. Bravo!

After scrolling a long way down the comments, I'm not seeing anything that explains the entry under SPIRAL in my Oxford American Dictionary phone app. Here, for your delectation, is the relevant text:

VERB
spirals, spiraling, spiraled *American Football* spirals, spiralling, spiralled

The text I've marked with ** is emphasized in green, which indicates that what follows is a specific usage. That is, they're indicating that the "ll" forms are specific to American Football.
This was good, clean fun. Nothing too obscure and I finished it in enough time that I feel smart for once.
Terrific puzzle!  Congratulations on both your first publication and your graduation!

Congratulations on your puzzle and graduation!

This was a fun one that felt perfect for a Tuesday; just the right difficulty, and I especially loved seeing PELE & Jackie CHAN together!
Congrats for this and good luck this fall at SDSU, Tarun! Nice work!

Excellent crossword today.
I keep forgetting about 'overtime' which I associate solely with the workplace; in sport it's always 'extra time.'

I've never tasted Reeses chocolate, because:

 "The claim that American chocolate tastes like vomit is a       widespread bit somewhat inaccurate description."
Only somewhat.
But,
 "Some may find the sour taste of American chocolate refreshing."
I enjoyed this, no matter the age of the constructor.
Impressive debut! Especially from someone so young! You've given me impetus to try my own hand at puzzle construction, something I've been considering for a while now!
Really enjoyed this puzzle!

When there isn't a Munster-Mike pun.
The Comments just aren't as much fun
Is he off on vacation?
Or wants more stimulation?
Today's like a day without sun!
I am reminded of what Churchill said about Britain and America. ‚ÄúTwo nations divided by a common language.‚Äù
Unimaginative. Would have been better suited for a Monday.

Congratulations on graduating HS and constructing this puzzle for NYT. My daughter will be attending OSU Honors College this fall in Biochem and Molecular Biology. Have fun at SDSU. Your parents must be very proud!

Congratulations -- a very nice accomplishment for a pre-high-school-graduate!

My niece took her last final (a 6-hour math test!) at SDSU last Wednesday.  Too bad you won't have a chance to meet her!

Good luck with all your endeavors!!

Just reading an article about a 10th century Viking burial site discovered in Denmark; "One of the graves, which scientists believe belonged to an important woman, contained a box filled with decorative objects and a pair of scissors."

Wow, a Viking ETUI, Who knew?

Also, I thought of a third answer for 37A, but it's unprintable.

Very impressive for a high school student! Smooth fill, fun but not challenging ‚Äî¬†just right for a Tuesday. 

Meanwhile there's crossword constructors more than twice his age who struggle not to stuff their puzzles with the most obscure trivia + crosswordese...

This was a very sophisticated puzzle for such a young constructor. Bravo, Tarun! Descartes' famous "I think, therefore I am" graced my bedroom wall in my parent's home, with my own drawing of a human figure sitting against the trunk of a tree. I did a lot of thinking (and writing) as a teenager... It was wonderful to be reminded of that, but the magical touch of this puzzle, for me, was seeing the concealed Maurice RAVEL of Bolero fame. It took me straight to YouTube to revisit Maurice B√©jart's masterpiece choreography for it, one that requires of a dancer nothing less than precision and stamina as it perfectly interprets the crescendo of the musical piece. https://youtu.be/m5CFJlzlGKM?si=xBLH1OmJsrsxvl_B Tarun, congratulations on your debut as a NYT xword constructor, and best wishes for successful college years ahead!
Thank you, Tarun Krishnamurthy, for an excellent puzzle that was also lots of fun. Hope your time at SDSU is happy and productive. I‚Äôm betting you will graduate with honors.
I really enjoyed this puzzle. Thank you Tarun and best of luck at college!
Congrats to the author! I have to say, I've never heard a single person ever use the phrase "Presses the Flesh" though. Felt very out of place.
Congrats Tarun, excellent puzzle with a few surprises I enjoyed very much.
Nice. I got hung up for a bit thinking it was "core beliefs"... might say I developed a firm belief in the wrong answer lol
Taran, you seem like a bright and well-balanced person.  Enjoy your time in San Diego.  It's a beautiful city.

Loved the puzzle and it completes a100-day streak since my hip replacement after a fracture (minus the first couple narcotic-infused post-op days). Quite a BASH after I was run into while skiing at Whistler in March. Surgery left my bone-SPURred, cartilage-free femoral head in the *bucket*, which has the same number of letters as BREAST. Fortunately it wasn't a SPIRALled fracture. 

I usually haven't bothered with streaks, but the forced inactivity started this one and then I decided to continue. This past weekend, I was late getting to the Friday puzzle and did it in order on Saturday, before starting the Saturday one, and was rewarded with a blue star, which I think breaks the streak. In the past, I have sometimes waited two days before completing puzzles and always got the gold star as long as the puzzles were done in order. This was my understanding after reading many discussions about this in the commentariat in the past. I inquired of the NYT Games staff, and a nice woman wrote me "... for a puzzle to count toward your streak, it must have been solved on the day of its publication before midnight without having used in-app help...It doesn't count if it 's within 24 hours unfortunately."

I followed up with her but haven't heard back. I didn't know about the constraint of not seeking help from "in-app" resources, which I never look at until after completing the puzzle. Others might be interested or have some insight. FWIW I'm doing very well thanks to modern surgery!

This was fun. Congrats on the acceptance and graduating high school! What big accomplishments.
Thank you for mentioning the Crosscord server too - I was wondering if crossword folks had made their way there yet! (however the link does not go to the server...if someone could fix that, please and thank you)

Minor quibble with the British spelling "SPIRALLED" being used when the clue is in reference to an American sport, but aside from that fun puzzle with a neat and well done theme. 

I do not have the issue above with "THEATRE" since the clue indicates it is British.
What are the rules on grid symmetry? This one seems to be left right symmetrical whereas I thought they had to be diagonally symmetrical
Well done! Happy grad!
Thanks, Tarun. Your puzzle was fun! :D
Congratulations on your graduation, Tarun, and on this fun puzzle!  I enjoyed it, and now I want one of your theme candies. Good luck going forward, you have a bright future.
Lovely puzzle and one of my favorite candies.  The most orgasmic version is the Reeses bar.

Such a fun puzzle, Tarun!  Congratulations on your graduation and best wishes as you embark on your college adventure.  I hope we see more of your crossword work in the future.  

I continue to be awed by the level of puzzle making skill the teens and young college students have been showing with their witty and challenging puzzles.  I look forward to more of the same.
Thoroughly enjoyable and witty. My only gripe: elFIN?! Elven is the rational & logical answer here. Drove me a bit crazy but we got there in the end.
Tarun, your triumphant clue for TEEN legit gave me a huge smile! Congrats on your crossword debut, your high school graduation, and the launch of your college era. Exciting times!

@Josh, I had never heard of contronyms, mentioned in the article for RAVEL, so I looked it up, and one of the examples is "to dust", which can mean either to remove dust, such as while cleaning the bookshelf, or to add dust, for example while looking for fingerprints. Primed with that, I initially had a surely mistaken but also ambiguous and hilarious reading of your comment. :-)

@Josh
This was my reaction to realizing, via the crossword, that the Thong Song was 25 years old. At what point does it become an oldie?
@polymath  -  Technically, it was.

@CaptainQuahog

Yeah, I have some crowns that are over 40, and I keep thinking eventually they're going to need replacing.

BTW, it's really good to see a post from you now and then.  I do miss when you were a regular.

I also understand the desire to go into lurk mode.

@Francis - All went well. This is a new dentist to me -- was recommended to me by a friend whose father was one of the more beloved dentists in the Bangor area. If she recommends a dentist, I believe her! 

The original crown was put in by a dentist I first used in 1980. I moved away from that town in 1984. So I have a pretty good window on the age of the crown -- 41-45 years old. I remember asking him how long a crown should last -- he said "typically, about 40 years." He was pretty spot-on!

@RichardZ

Yes! I kept waiting for the clue about the ‚Äúalien space crew‚Äù, but it never happened.

@Andrzej

You may not like it still, but I think the connection is that the candy Reese's Pieces are little round candies, kind of like an M&M shape and size If you have M&M's. 

They come from the original Reese's Peanut Butter Cups, which which are larger maybe a standard cookie size in diameter. They are peanut butter coated in chocolate.  

The Reese's pieces are also peanut butter and covered in chocolate but with a coating, sort of like an M&M coating, and like I said above small round pieces. 

I wonder if you'd have gotten more presents if you had left cookies and milk or even Reese's pieces for Santa..  üòâ

@Andrzej

I still believed in Santa when most of my friends didn't, and I also got teased mercilessly. I don't remember how old I was, but much older than six. My mom pulled me into the kitchen on Christmas Eve and broke the news to me. My next question was, "What about the Easter Bunny?" No, that's not real either. "The tooth fairy?" Nope. 

Interestingly, I didn't even think to ask the big question, "What about God?" That didn't happen until I was 17 and realized for myself that none of the religion stuff I'd been taught made sense either.

The way she softened the blow about Santa was to emphasize that she was letting me in on a secret that my brothers and sisters didn't know, and said I could help put out the presents from Santa after they went to bed. Is this why my sibs resent me to this day? ü§£

@Francis And mine is Dwight Yoakum singing (Mama said) "Santa Can't Stay"... https://youtu.be/MW7b3WwQxcE?si=C1aFFEuLCqHz7V1f Or The Kinks' "Father Christmas". I'm sure a pop psychologist would have a field day with that admission! Haha -- I mean ho ho ho!

@Beth in Greenbelt

My epiphany about God came in second grade, when my class learned about the Iroquois creation myth. They believed that the earth was created on the back of a turtle, after a great tree fell from the land of the Sky People into the waters below. When the pregnant daughter of the chief fell through the hole left by the tree, the animals in the water below came together to save her. They built her a home on the back of a giant turtle, using the dirt from the fallen tree roots. Magically, this dirt expanded to cover the turtle and create the island world the Iroquois inhabited.

While my classmates howled at the idea that anyone could believe they lived on a turtle‚Äôs back, I was struck by the realization that a myth is a myth, and so how was the Garden of Eden any more believable? Or any of the other stories? It was a huge awakening.

I do think myths have their place, as a way to teach values and kind behavior. It‚Äôs when they are taken as facts, and twisted to justify intolerance or atrocities that I have a problem. I also think there‚Äôs no way my teacher would be allowed to share that turtle story today.

@Heidi

Many years ago, it dawned on me that all the Roman and Greek mythology I learned in ninth grade was actually those ancient people's religion.

And it followed that any religious stories that are no longer believed become relegated to the category of myth.

Those who lived in the Greek and Roman dynasties thought they would last forever.  We have the hubris to believe our particular culture will last forever.  Already, there are cracks in the armor; most of Europe is very secular, and Christianity no longer has the same hold over the US that it once did.  How long until people will believing in something that hasn't even arrived yet?

And yet the myths live on; we tell the stories that no one takes literally anymore.  People who have walked away from religion still celebrate Christmas secularly.  Thor becomes a  Marvel Comics hero, and namesake of a day of the week (as do four other gods).

Human nature is peculiar, to say the least.

@Andrzej Useless trivia cluttering my brain: Reese's Pieces shot to candy fame because they were featured in the hit movie ET. Elliot uses them to lure ET into a trap. The movie folks offered the "role" to M&Ms, but Mars turned them down. I'm not sure the candy would have succeeded otherwise. It's pretty dull, IMHO.

Welcome to the comments, and make yourself at home:-)

@Beth in Greenbelt

I just realized the generation classification thing poorly applies over here, especially to people older than me (born in 1980).

Our world changed completely, and anything that happened before 1989 can't really be evaluated under "Western" standards. Thus, we don't really have a Boomer generation - of course, Poland changed greatly after 1945, and generally living standards improved immeasurably, especially in the country, but under totally different conditions than in the "West". There was no wealth accumulation, for example, since it was basically impossible to become wealthy in the ultra-egalitarian, pre-1989 world.

Only once Poland opened up in 1989 did it re-enter the world's mainstream, and that included social transformations that shaped (younger) Gen Xers, Millennials, and the later generations.

Looking at the definitions and characteristics, I am a blend of Gen X and Millennial, and I find it impossible to identify more closely with either of the two classifications.

@Beth in Greenbelt
Never really bought into the "Gen" thing. Creates too many stereotypes based on an arbitrary starting point.

@Hanson
Yes!  The last thing we need are more categories used to separate us.

@Hanson

I realized this last night when I started thinking about it. For every characteristic I thought of, I then thought of people I know who don't fit.
@Hanson definitely feels arbitrary. The first time I learned about the generations, Boomers ended at 1959 (when my sister was born). Now it is defined as 1963 (when my husband was born).

I think there's usefulness in having the generation categories. I tend to look at it for ways to understand people better and not separate, and it helps me do that. To me, understanding what generation someone is helps me understand the world in which they grow up in as pertains to major events, trends, and the social and political norms of the time. Those things can say something about how they view the world and interact within it. 

As Gen X, I was afraid of quicksand, it always seemed like a threat and I'm amazed that I haven't encountered it yet. But I never once thought that we would be attacked like 9/11 on American soil. That's just one of many examples but I think that those experiences in your developing years can make a difference and understanding and appreciating differences can bring us together.

It's a general guide as long as no one thinks of it as hard and fast. There's all sorts of ways that it won't strictly apply to everyone.

@Steve L My American Heritage Dictionary offers SPIRALLED as an alternate spelling, with no indication of its alleged Britishness. Ditto Merriam-Webster: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/spiral It may be that a British or Canadian person would never spell it with a single L, but that‚Äôs doesn‚Äôt mean that the one L version is wrong or even less common in American English.

@Eric Hougland In ESL class, we taught the rule that an unstressed final consonant is not doubled, because that's how it usually is. ESL teaching is based on what is done, not what the experts say. Here's the Ngram proof that "spiraled" is by far the more common spelling in the US: https://tinyurl.com/4a948ss6 Sure, some Americans use the double-consonant versions of such words from time to time, but those are the exceptions. Chris Stapleton's breakthrough album in 2015 was called "Traveller". https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traveller_(Chris_Stapleton_album) Brits mostly use the double-letter version, but even there, the single-letter version is fairly common. In fact, there's much less space between the two: https://tinyurl.com/56wustde So the double-letter forms are far less common, and more likely to be associated with British usage. I never said the puzzle had an error, but it does seem strange.

@Helen Wright

In the orthography of American English, if the emphasis is on the first syllable of a word, then the final consonant is not doubled if one is adding -ed or -ing,  

Think of rebut....rebutted, rebutting; (or caper or major)

Now, how would you spell the past or present participle or the past tense of the verbs  combat, permit, or upset?

Thus SPIral would not require doubling the L.

@Mean Old Lady
I hear you. Another example of where English and American English differs. We would double the consonant. Why? Absolutely no idea. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

@Helen Wright

In American English, two-syllable verbs only take a doubled final consonant before -ed and -ing when that's the stressed syllable, so "controlled," "averred," "repelled," etc.  Also, this only happens when the next-to-last letter is a vowel, so "discarded," "reported," "avoided," etc.

Otherwise, you don't double that final consonant, so "traveled," "simmered," "happened," etc.  I think this agrees with British usage.  Some words, like "canceled," are also seen with the doubled letter, "cancelled."

W, X and Y are exceptions, so "yellowed," "faxed," and "obeyed."

It's travelled though. Most spelling rules get broken, don't they.

@Sam Corbin

"Caber" is originally just a wooden pole, used in building. (It's from Gaelic "cabar", meaning, well, pole.) The sport was originally "tossing the bar"---we didn't start "tossing the caber" until the nineteenth century, when the "Highland Games" were concocted as part of the general invention of "Scottish tradition" by a few folk in Edinburgh.

@Mardee That was my experience when I was in theatre as well. Just as we tended to say "actor" for both male and female performers. Didn't mean we never said "actress," but tended not to when talking to another actor.

@Oikofuge
We go down (or up) garden paths in the US too.

@Oikofuge

Unlike a spherical British football, for which each diameter can serve as an axis of rotational symmetry, an American football has a unique axis of rotational symmetry. If thrown properly, by making correct use of the laces on its surface, the ball will rotate about its axis as it travels. So, relative to the ball itself, each point on the surface will travel in a circle about the ball's axis. So I suppose that each point "spirals" around the roughly parabolic arc traced out by the ball's center of mass. In any case, a perfectly thrown football "spirals" in a manner that minimizes air resistance, allowing it to fly faster and farther.

@Xword Junkie
True, but you would spiral a rugby ball for an accurate long (lateral) pass. There is no forward passing in that game, except by kicking the ball.

@RozzieGrandma

(Though now I've actually written that down, it seems very likely to me that it was poor Herbert who broke the joke.)

@Oikofuge

I don‚Äôt see that distinction in any other dictionaries, and it runs counter to my experience. Those doubled consonants just look British to me, and I don‚Äôt remember ever seeing the movement of an American football with that spelling.

@Oikofuge, 
Somehow, I never noticed the double L spelling as a distinction between BrE and AmE, as much as -ise versus -ize, anyway. I did flinch a bit when SPIRALING wasn't long enough. What else could it be?

@Oikofuge

It's a puzzle. Here, just to show I'm not misunderstanding the entry, is the relevant section of the Oxford English Dictionary app on my phone:

VERB
(spirals, spiralling, spiralled; *US English* spirals, *US English* spiraling, *US English* spiraled)

@Grant The -ise/-ize distinction has only really become a distinction in the last fifty years or so. The Oxford English Dictionary still favours -ize in British English, and it was the preferred spelling in most British "prestige" publications well into the 1980s. It coexisted with the Frenchified -ise spelling for centuries in British English---Johnson used both -ize and -ise rather indiscriminately in his famous Dictionary, for instance, but Noah Webster later came down heavily for -ize in his American Spelling Book. I was taught -ize at school, and still use it. And it's still frequently encountered in British publications, despite the definite shift towards -ise in recent years. So I'm often bemused by how many British English speakers think that -ize is some sort of creeping Americanism, rather than a standard BrE spelling which is now waning. For more detail, see here: https://oikofuge.com/ize/

@Oikofuge
 I‚Äôm surprised at all the discussion of this word. 
I know American English is fraught with varying confusing pronunciations, but one thing is most often true, a vowel followed  by one consonant and then another vowel would be a long vowel‚Ä¶so spiraling would be pronounced with a long A like cake, and spiralling would be pronounced with a short A like cat, which is how we say it‚Ä¶at least in America. 
I filled in spiralling without a second thought, and can‚Äôt say if that is how I‚Äôve always spelled it‚Ä¶not sure I have ever been called to do so before. ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

@Jane Wheelaghan

In baseball, it's extra innings.  In American football, basketball and hockey, the other three major sports here, it's overtime.

In tennis, it's a tiebreaker.  In golf, it's a playoff.

In soccer, it's extra time, just like in the rest of the world, but then again, soccer is the only sport I'm aware of where the clock counts up.  And when you reach full time, you've played through the 90-minute mark, and some unknown number of minutes determined by how much time was wasted when the clock kept on running because you're not allowed to stop it.  At least in American sports, we know how much playing time is left near the end of a game.

Steve,

You would be happier with U.S. college soccer, where (a) the clock counts down and (b) the clock does stop for stoppages so there is no stoppage time after 0:00.

@Steve L 
We know how long is left in soccer because we can do simple subtraction. Plus they let you know straight away how many minutes of injury time there'll be.
Also, when a team plays for time, the ref will add extra time, too, even though play was not stopped. It makes sense.

@Jane Wheelaghan

May I ask where that sad quote about American chocolate came from?

@HeathieJ

it's been running about the internet for a few years now, that some ingredient in Hershey's chocolate is related to some chemical in vomit. 
It is true that Hershey's milk chocolate is not as sweet or creamy as other milk chocolates, particularly European milk chocolates. Hershey's milk chocolate is just a bit more bitter, more of a tang like dark chocolate.
I grew up eating Hershey's, so I prefer it, but it is off-putting if one is expecting milk chocolate to be like the English Cadbury's.

@Linda Jo

Butyric acid is the offending chemical. It's the stuff that makes parmesan cheese smell the way it does, and it can be present in vomit if fatty acids have been broken down in the stomach, a process called lipolysis.
It's suggested that American chocolatiers are inducing lipolysis in the milk they use, but of course the process is a trade secret.

(While the chemistry is interesting, I actually don't care much for chocolate, so can't comment on the taste.)

@Andrzej

Well, I don't know about Poland, but in the US the referees would get rich by taking money to manipulate the amount of  "injury time". 

For example, the Kansas City Chiefs, if behind at 0:00 would obviously get extra time.  It used to be that the New England Patriots would get extra time, but now it's the Chiefs.  

A common consolation talk a father gives his children about football:  "Well, maybe next year the Las Vegas gamblers will decided that *our* team should win.

By convention, not rule, most symmetry is diagonal, but there are frequent variations and, at times, grids that are asymmetric. Stay tuned.

@Paul

First of all, there are no rules.  

Secondly, you're right that this puzzle has left-right, aka mirror symmetry.  

Most often, I've seen 2-fold rotational symmetry.  This means that in you were to turn the entire puzzle around the 
center point by 180 degrees, you see the same white/black pattern.

I think I've seen that this 2-fold rotational symmetry is the standard.

But there are no rules.

@Francis

I agree; 180¬∞ rotational symmetry is the most common type.
